title: A Novel Riemannian Framework for Shape Analysis of 3D Objects

author: Sebastian Kurtek, Department of Statistics, Florida State University

segmentation: Good morning, my name is Sebastian Krtek.
Today I'll present a novel Riemannian framework for a shape analysis of 3D objects.
Before I begin, I would like to thank the other authors of this paper.
Doctors Eric class in Java Edingen under Travis Diva.
I would also like to acknowledge the grants that support this research from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research.
The Office of Naval Research and the National Science Foundation.
In that, in order to motivate the problem at hand, let us consider the following two parents right surfaces.

First, we would like to view these surfaces as continuous entities and we would like to compare the shapes of these surfaces using a metric that is invariant to scale translation, rotation, Anri penetration.
There are many applications of such a framework for shape analysis of 3D objects.
These include medical image analysis, bioinformatics, facial recognition, geology, image matching and many others.
Let me also briefly mention some of the current methods in shape analysis.
These include the formal templates, level set methods, landmarks, or active shape models.
The iterative closest point algorithm, and medial representation methods.
Unfortunately, none of these methods analyze shapes of surface parameterized surfaces directly, which is the goal of our research.
So to set up the problem, let us denote a 2DS smooth and differentiable surface.

We can define apparent translation of Surface S as F, which is a mapping from the unit sphere, two or three, and we can define the set of all such penetrations as script F. We let gamma be the set of all diffeomorphisms of S2 in the natural action of gamma and script F is on the right by composition or F composed with gamma.
But in General, Gamma is not area preserving and therefore the isometry condition is not satisfied under the L2 metric.
That is, given two surfaces F1 and F2, if we repair and tries them by the same gamma, Delta distance will not be preserved.
There are two current solutions to this problem.

The first one is to simply restrict to area preserving repatriations only, but this proves to be very limiting in practice, and the other solution is to fix the penetration of all surfaces prior to the analysis, such as done by's form.
Our approach is different.
That is, we introduce a new representation of surfaces such that the isometry condition is satisfied under the L2 metric.

So given a differentiable surface F, we define Kappa to be the area multiplication factor of F. And then we use Kaplan F to define AQ Map, which is a mapping from S, two or three as Q S = 2 squared of Kappa vest Times F of S.
As I stated earlier, we want to achieve certain invariances in our framework.
Two of two of the variations can be removed directly.
That is, we scale all services to have unit area an we translate all of our services such that the center of mass is located at the origin.
Now if one wishes to include these variations in the analysis, these steps can simply be skipped.
The other two types of variation that is rotation, repair isation are removed using algebraic operations.
Order to do this, we have to define their group actions on the space of Q Maps.

So given a rotation matrix, oh, the action of the rotation group is defined as oh times Q and given a repatriation gamma, the action of the repair Translation Group is defined as the square root of the Jacobian of gamma Times Q composed with gamma.
And it is easy to check now that the isometry condition is satisfied under the L2 metric.

Given these tools, we can define an equivalence class of a Q map is all possible rotations and repairing translations of that Q map we define the shape space is the quotient space of script F. Remove the product group.
Grant Gamma Cross S 03.
We we now define the distance between surfaces as the distance between the orbits of the Q Maps, which is governed by the following joint minimization problem over SO3 and gamma.
And the solution to this optimization problem is twofold.

Given a fixed parent risation, we can solve for the optimal rotation using procrustes analysis and we can solve for the optimal repatriation using a gradient descent algorithm and our approach will be to search for the optimal rotation to iterate between optimize getting the optimal rotation in the optimal reprioritization until we converge at these solution.
The optimization problem over gamma is quite involved, and I'll describe some details right now.
At the current step, we define the energy E of gamma an in this energy gamma not is fixed and it is just the current penetration of the second Q, Matt.
Gamma in this formula is a variable.
We define the mapping field gamma, which is the currently parametrised Q2 repair tries by gamma.
The Jacobian of Field Gamma is defined as 1/2 times divergences, B dot Q~ plus the grading of Q~ dot BB.
Here is an orthonormal basis of the unit sphere, and Q~ is the currently parent.
Tries Q 2.
Given this, we use the directional derivative of our energy function to obtain our solution and below I just provide 4 examples of the orthonormal basis elements for the unit sphere domain.
Because we use a gradient descent algorithm, the initialization of the gradient search becomes very important.

The way we do this for the unit sphere domain is by optimizing over 60 elements in the group of symmetries of the dodecahedron, which is equivalent to placing the North Pole at 60 different in 60 different locations, and on this slide I provide the faces of the dodecahedron in the 60 different possible locations of the North Pole on the unit sphere.
I also give an example.
Of this initialization were given two surfaces F1 and F2.
I provide the energy minimizer due to this initialization and the cost function itself.
So given the framework I just defined, I'll now provide some examples of computing distances between surfaces and matching surfaces.
Before I do that, I would like to explain how displayed the matching.

I provide the optimally rotate and repairing tries second surface.
I give the magnitude of the grid deformation on the second surface where light areas correspond to high levels of grid deformation.
I provide the final distance between the surfaces and the energy at each iteration.

An one thing to note on this slide is that even though the surfaces are very similar to begin with, we still achieve a nearly a 30% decrease in the energy function due to optimization over the Repatriation Group.
And I also have a movie that displays this process.
And we can clearly see the grid forming on the second surface.
The second example I have is of matching the left pyramid surface in the left thalamus surface.
Again, I displayed the same results.
Here we can clearly see the effects of initializing the gradient search.
Again, I give the final distance between the surfaces.
The energy at each iteration.
Again, we see a significant decrease in the energy due to our optimization.
And again I have a movie that displays this process.
We used our methodology to perform an ADHD classification and here I have results for single structure classification results.
We were given a T1 weighted brain magnetic resonance images of young adults of ages between 13 and 17 and they were recruited from the Detroit fetal Alcohol and drug exposure cohort.
The data given were left and right brain structures.
There were a total of 11 of them for 34 subjects, 19 with ADHD and 15 who are healthy.
And we use the leave one out nearest neighbor classification scheme.

The results are provided in the table and we see that using our method, the best the best classifier was the left putamen and we also see that our method compares very favorably to the currently used methods like icy piores form PDM.

We extended this study to include our multiple structure classification the way we did this was we combined weighted single structure distances in order to maximize the ADHD classification rate by combining the distances of left putamen, left politics and right political structures, we obtained the 91 percent disease classification rate and below I provide the multidimensional scale plot for the 34 subjects and sorted distance matrix.
And we see some nice separation between the ADHD cases and controls.
So far I've presented the framework and results for shape analysis of close services only, but this framework is easily extendable to quadrilateral surfaces which are defined on the unit square.
Ann hemispherical surfaces, which are defined on the unit disk.
Here's an example of matching two quadrilateral surfaces.
We're given 2 images of handwritten 0 digit.

We can view the pixel values in these images as height functions on the unit square.
And these results in quadrilateral surfaces.

I also give the final matching result the optimal repatriation gamma star.
The energy at each iteration and the final distance between the two surfaces.

That shows this repatriation process, and we see the zeros aligning very nicely.
Here I have a similar example.
We're interested in matching the digit three and the digit 6.
Again, we view them as quadrilateral surfaces.
I provide the final matching result.

The energy at each iteration and again we see that most of the white areas disappear when we showed the absolute difference in pixel values, which means that the matching was greatly improved by applying our framework.
And again, here we can see the improvement in alignment.
Here we have an example of matching two hemispherical surfaces.
In particular, these are cropped faces and the two surfaces here are very similar to begin with, so the grid deformation is fairly subtle.
Nonetheless, we still see a significant decrease in the energy function due to optimization over the Repatriation Group.
We also see a very intuitive result that is the most grid deformation.
A curd in the area of the lips cheeks and the eyes, which is where the two surfaces differ most and we can actually see this happening in this movie.
Here we see the grid clearly the forming around the lips.
In order to show the benefits of using our method, we computed certain optimal paths between 2 toys shapes with and without optimizing over the repatriation group that is important.
Displayed paths are not geodesic with respect to our metric, but rather under metric described by killing at all in their 2007 paper.
And we see a very nice result here.
That is when we do not optimize over the repatriation Group, the features get very distorted as we go through the path, the surface path.
But when we apply our methodology and we obtain the optimal repatriation, we see that the features are nicely preserved, which is what we would like.
To conclude, shape analysis of 3D objects is very important in many scientific fields.
We have proposed a novel approach for the analysis of 3D objects, which is invariant to rigid motion scaling and most importantly repatriation.

This results in the proper metric on the space of Q Maps and in the future would like to be able to show geodesics between surfaces with respect to our metric as well as to apply this data applied this methodology and more.
Data thank you for this opportunity to present our research.
And are there any questions?
We have time for one quick question.
Why your?
So the question I think was to give examples where our method outperforms other methods.
Why you?
Well our why our method is better than other methods.
Well, one example was shown in this geodesic path.
So if we're if we're interested in having a very natural path between surfaces, we see from this, even though this is not with respect to our metric, we see that this path.
Looks much nicer when we apply our methodology rather than assuming a fixed parametrization on both surfaces.
And we have also run.
I mean another example I guess is in this ADHD classification study.
Where we see that our performance is quite good compared to the other methods currently used.
So let's thank the speaker again.
